review.title: Fuzzy Adaptive Resonance Theory, Diffusion Maps and their applications to Clustering and Biclustering
review.abstract: In this paper, we describe an algorithm FARDiff (Fuzzy Adaptive Resonance Dif- fusion) which combines Diffusion Maps and Fuzzy Adaptive Resonance Theory to do clustering and biclustering on high dimensional data. We describe some applications of this method.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we describe an algorithm called FARDiff (Fuzzy Adaptive Resonance Diffusion) that combines diffusion maps and fuzzy adaptive resonance theory to perform clustering on high-dimensional data, an algorithm described in the papers [9, 10, 18, 19, 21]. We describe some applications of this method and some problems for future research. sections.heading: 4. Applications in Cancer Detection and Hyperspectral Clustering
sections.text: The algorithm we are discussing in this paper, which we call FARDiff (Cold Adaptive Resonance Diffusion), combines 1. Diffusion Cards and 2. Fuzzy Adaptive Resonance Theory to cluster based on high-dimensional data, an algorithm that was presented in the papers [9, 10,18,19,21]. In [18, 21] we applied FARDiff to investigate the detection of cancer. Early detection of the origin of a tumor is particularly important for cancer diagnosis and treatment, and the use of 4 "clusters" and "biclustering" - 2015 / 10 / 7 - 4: 03 - Page 5 - # 5i ii igene expression profiles for different cancer types or subtypes has already shown significant advantages over conventional methods of cancer classification. We applied FARDiff to the small circular blue tumor cells (SRBCT) to measure the amount of data obtained from diagnostic studies of small children with blue tumors.

sections.heading: 5. Open Questions For Future Research
sections.text: In this section we will discuss some of the ongoing work. We are interested in extending the FARDiff algorithm to a two-dimensional framework and a high-dimensional data reduction. Biclustering is a technique that performs simultaneous clustering in many dimensions, which automatically integrates feature selection to cluster formation without prior information. Two examples of good two-dimensional algorithms are BARTMAP and HBiFAM (Hierarchical Biclustering FA algorithm) [16,22].It is known that clustering is widely used in the analysis of high-throughput messenger RNA (mRNA) expression profiling with microarrays. This technique is restrictive, in part, due to the existence of many uncorrelated genes in terms of example or state clustering formation, or many non-related samples or conditions in terms of gene clustering. Biclustering provides a solution to such problems by simultaneously performing cluster formation based on both-dimensional or automatic feature selection.
